title: Export grants review aims to streamline payments
text:
Trade Minister Simon Birmingham is launching a review of the $160 million in annual government grants for export market development, to help streamline payments to small and medium enterprises expanding their sales overseas.

The export market development grants (EMDG) scheme reimburses firms with turnover below $50 million some of the costs of their overseas marketing and promotion activities, such as attending trade shows and social media advertising campaigns.

A shortcoming of the existing scheme is that SMEs applying for grants have to spend their own money initially and lack certainty as to how much government financial support they will later be paid.

The application process also takes longer than ideal for time-poor SMEs and they have to wait until the end of the financial year to receive their final government reimbursement.

The EMDG repays up to 50 per cent of eligible export market development expenses in excess of $5000, up to a maximum of $150,000 per firm a year.

However, strong demand and oversubscription by SMEs in recent years has led to a maximum grant of $66,000 per business.
description: The Morrison government will review the $160 million in annual government grants for export market development to streamline payments to SMEs.
